problem_statement: In distributed stream processing, data frequently arrives out of sequence due to network partitions or latency. A robust aggregator cannot rely on the server's wall-clock time (time.Now) to close windows, as this leads to inaccurate results when processing backlogged data. Instead, the system must implement logical clock progression via Watermarksâ€”a heuristic that asserts that no events older than a certain timestamp will arrive. The engineering complexity lies in the dual responsibility of the Watermark: it determines the precise moment a window is mathematically complete (triggering emission) and signals the safe point for memory reclamation. Failing to implement aggressive, event-driven garbage collection results in unbounded memory growth (state explosion) as the map of windows grows indefinitely over time.
